commander.name: Major-General Noel Beresford-Peirse
commander.previous_service: Commanded division through Operation Compass, transferred to East African Campaign December 1940

composition_notes: British Indian Army division with mixed British and Indian infantry battalions. Approximately 40% British personnel, 60% Indian personnel across all ranks.

Matilda II Infantry Tank.notes: 4 Matildas from 7th RTR at Battle of Agordat (January 1941)

Light Tank Mk VI.notes: Central India Horse reconnaissance regiment equipment

Universal Carrier (Bren Gun Carrier).notes: Used extensively at Agordat and Keren

QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.organization: Three field regiments (1st, 25th, 31st Field Regiments RA), each with 24 guns in three batteries of 8 guns
QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.notes: Primary divisional artillery, highly effective at Keren

QF 2-pounder Anti-Tank Gun.organization: Brigade anti-tank companies and divisional anti-tank regiment

QF 3.7-inch Heavy AA Gun.notes: Limited heavy AA capability in East Africa

Ordnance ML 3-inch Mortar.organization: 9 battalions × 6 mortars per battalion (2 per company, approximate)

reconnaissance.notes: Division had no organic aircraft; air support provided by RAF squadrons

supply_status.notes: Supply situation in East Africa challenging due to terrain and distance from ports

subordinate_units.notes: Fought at Agordat and Keren; later detached to Syria campaign (June 1941)
Spearheaded assault on Cameron Ridge at Keren; noted for fierce fighting capability
Brigade composition verified for 1941; Brigadier Briggs commanded during Keren operations

subordinate_units.unit_designation: Central India Horse (21st King George V's Own Horse)
subordinate_units.equipment_note: Light tanks and Indian Pattern Carriers
subordinate_units.notes: Mechanized cavalry regiment serving as divisional reconnaissance; fought in East Africa and later North Africa
Three field regiments provided outstanding fire support at Keren
Three field companies provided engineering support; critical for mountain warfare at Keren
Managed logistics in challenging East African terrain

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division configured for combined arms operations in both desert and mountain terrain
special_capabilities: Experienced in desert warfare from Operation Compass (December 1940)
Adapted to mountain warfare during East African Campaign (January-March 1941)
Mixed British-Indian composition provided language skills and cultural knowledge
Strong infantry-artillery coordination demonstrated at Keren
tactical_innovations: Effective use of Matilda tanks in infantry support role at Agordat
Coordinated multi-brigade assaults on fortified mountain positions
Integration of Indian Army mountain warfare expertise
known_issues: Limited armored support (only 4 Matildas available at Agordat)
Long supply lines in East Africa created logistical challenges
Shortage of medium and heavy artillery for mountain warfare
Limited air support due to RAF priorities elsewhere
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division had extensive desert experience from Operation Compass but was redeployed to mountainous terrain in Eritrea, requiring tactical adaptation

operations_1941_q1: Division transferred from Egypt to Sudan late December 1940
Replaced in Operation Compass by 6th Australian Division
Participated in Battle of Agordat (January 26-31, 1941) with 4 Matilda tanks
Fought Battle of Keren (February 3 - March 27, 1941), one of hardest-fought battles of East African Campaign
Cameron Highlanders captured 'Cameron Ridge' at Keren
Division demonstrated effectiveness of 25-pounder artillery in mountain warfare
command_changes: Major-General Beresford-Peirse commanded through end of March 1941
Beresford-Peirse appointed to Corps command in April 1941
historical_notes.casualties: Significant casualties at Keren; exact figures for Q1 1941 not available in sources
